body:
@rabbah @jasonpet @csantanapr 
I think the openwhisk-catalog is ready, this PR can be the first step to switch to openwhisk-catalog. After this one, actions can be removed gradually in openwhisk, and test cases will be changed accordingly.

Rebased and merged.  PG 79 is now running against latest blue/open
@rabbah - PG 79 passed (minus some timing related failure).  This PR is now successfully merged.

@houshengbo - other builds outside of travis run these tests as well.  If you change the package name of the tests from util to utils these others builds, which will not be flipped as part of this PR will fail.  Please contact me via slack if you do not now about the other builds I am referring to.  In my opinion these tests either need to move to the openwhisk-catalog repo or install the actions themselves via files in the tests/dat/actions folder.  That way tests in open would not need to depend on openwhisk-catalog being installed.

@houshengbo - I created a fix for WskActionSequenceTests.  You can pull my commit:
https://github.com/jasonpet/openwhisk/commit/260e5b346b420a6ab74ae35b2c6655054758d87c

@jasonpet Thank you. I have pulled the branch and update this PR.
I will continue to fix the WskBasicTests.

More notes from Slack conversations:
- For throttling purposes, an action that is executing as a result of a sequence invocation should not count as an additional action for the user. In other words, for a sequence with N actions,  only one should be taken into account for throttling purposes. Not 100% sure but this may happen automatically since throttling happens before getting to the part that executes an action as part of a sequence. Need to double check that.
- We need to limit the number of actions within a sequence. Since sequence can refer to sequences, some recursive count is needed.
I'm taking over this PR while James is out.

@jasonpet If #952 will address the go-cli work, what's remaining to close this issue? Maybe #883 
But #883 depends on #952.

So correct me if I'm missing something.
To close this issue, it depends on update go-cli to address annotations correctly and then flip to use the go-cli to be use for installation.

@csantanapr - #952 is the issue I opened and is the real blocker one.  Annotation values were not parsed properly at all in go-cli.  This issue is for addressing the scenario where a user has a syntax error in there annotation value.  Before we were not throwing an error and were creating an invalid value (we created the type as String instead of JSON).  The fix for this issue would be to throw an error for invalid syntax.  #952 has to go in before we can flip to use go-cli.  It can be verified by manually flipping the switch to go-cli.
I'd like to request that we apply the same upgrade to `whisk.trigger()`.
LGTM, same as @psuter let's do `whisk.trigger()` also

> I'd like to request that we apply the same upgrade to whisk.trigger().

I totally agree. Can we handle that in a separate PR though? #932 is waiting for the `invoke()` enhancement, and I don't think it has any need for `trigger()` to return a promise.
Merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/461d9a8fd67113bafd09ff4cfd09cc67780b219a.
I don't think any of those are urgent? I'd rather have two consistent points (before and after the optional `next`).

> I'd rather have two consistent points (before and after the optional next).

Sounds reasonable.  I'll get on it.

@jasonpet @csantanapr @rabbah 

I found out that test cases tests/src/system/basic/WskBasicTests.scala are different from in  tests/src/system/basic/WskActionSequenceTests.scala. 

I was trying to creating the action before calling the actions themselves, but I did  not succeed.
wskprops uses the guest auth key and "_" as the namespace. If I manually change it into the system auth key and whisk.system as the namespace, it tells me I am unable to create the action, since HTTP only expects "GET"; if I contribute to use the guest auth key and the namespace "_", I can still delete the action even if I change the auth key to something else. I am unable to create the valid test case for 

```
    it should "reject deleting action in shared package not owned by authkey" in {
        wsk.action.get("/whisk.system/util/cat") // make sure it exists
        wsk.action.delete("/whisk.system/util/cat", expectedExitCode = FORBIDDEN)
    }
```

and the similar ones.

I have not found any other ways to do it except changing util to utils, because we change this name in catalog repos. I am not sure if we are OK with this approach so far.
i'm working on rules enabled by default

I don't follow `HTTP only expects "GET"`  ?
when the cut is done, tests should not depend on artifacts (catago/system) to be installed first. 
The openwhisk runtime should not depend on a catalog to be installed to be able to work correctly. 
Looking at the tests cases it look they belong to in openwhisk and not catalog.
You will need to configure the tests to install a dummy/fixture package to be able to run the basic tests that verify that an user can't delete or modify a shared package without having the correct auth key. For the sequences it's just testing that sequences can be created with actions and the the sequence can be executed correctly, also can be fixture actions it's not important the functionality of the actions, but that they can be chained usable by tests.

I would suggest get together with @jasonpet or @bjustin-ibm they are familiar with the test utilities classes, there might be a need to create some helper classes to install/uninstall system packages as fixtures to be use by the test cases.
closing as abandoned PR

Please submit new catalog content to the new repo [openwhisk-catalog](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog)

I can help create encrypted travis file with credentials

@lzbj @houshengbo Are you actively working on this, its very important to addresses important github package bug.

cc @bjustin-ibm
@bjustin-ibm this is one of the github bugs that are important to address soon.
@houshengbo Is this PR still valid? based on the other work going on with openwhisk-catalog migration.
@psuter What's the status on this PR? waiting for review, abandoned, ready?
This is active. A commit was pushed 2 hours ago.
Correct, thank you @csantanapr

@psuter What uses this class? Maybe this is a class that doesn't belong in open and it's for internal use?
Was not able to find any references to this code in the repo.
My bad, was sorting PRs by recent, I guess I picked from the wrong end, and just saw the "21 days ago"
Deferring to @markusthoemmes.

@starpit This changes the default state to enable/active when a rule is created right?

This means we need two more things:
1. Update docs (example says that it needs to use --enable so the rule is enable on creation)
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/docs/triggers_rules.md
2. With this change CLI users will not be able to create a rule that is disable anymore, the `--enable` flag on create doesn't make sense anymore, it means a new flag needs to be introduce (i.e. --disable) for `wsk rule create --disable rulename trigger action`

```
$ wsk rule create -h
usage: wsk rule create [-h] [-u AUTH] [--shared [{yes,no}]] [--enable]
                       name trigger action

positional arguments:
  name                  the name of the rule
  trigger               the trigger
  action                the action

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  -u AUTH, --auth AUTH  authorization key
  --shared [{yes,no}]   shared action (default: private)
  --enable              enable rule after creating it
```

cc @mdeuser

@rabbah suggests handling the client update separately. How generally do you handle docs changes? Rolled in, or separate PR (I would imagine that docs updates have a distinct set of reviewers, which led me to limit this to the controller change, but am happy to go with the standard practice)
Not yet used in open but will be useful for allowing activations to be retrieved by a prefix (of their id) for example.

Yeah that's OK other team members can take care of the doc and go-CLI changes. 

I was trying to note what were the impacts of these PR, and the fact that CLI changes have not being discuss before. 

Any other impacts from this PR?
Only applicable to cloudant? Or it works with CouchDB also?
The class is useful if you write a client to retrieve tailored information out of a database. (Only applicable to Cloudant deployments, though not necessarily Bluemix.)

To answer @csantanapr's question, the reason I haven't asked for a merge yet is because, up to some days ago, occasionally a failure showed up in the build (not killing a long running action fast enough). I never witnessed the failure locally. I have been trying to reproduce it, but now it seems it just won't show up again.
Thanks for the update @psuter 👍🏼
@csantanapr thanks for the help with this! i agree with the need to update the docs and the CLI.
Is there an issue for the required CLI updates?
@mdeuser not yet. we should discuss the terminology there. e.g. is it --no-enable? --no-start (this is the terminology of cf)?

If after a while there is feedback on requesting some type of flag `--not-enable` then this can be added to the CLI, but for now I prefer to not implement until we hear feedback from real users using the new behavior.

I know choosing default values are a pain to get right, but waiting some time and  feedback/analytics is a good way to land in correct place.
Needs investigation, to see if it's a bug in ansible or a bug in ourside on how we use the latest ansible.
I'ld suggest to at least have the doc changes in this PR. Having self-contained changes in a PR is pure goodness.
LGTM, good catch!

but the docs only refer to operation of the CLI. this is not an API schema update, this is a semantic update. so by this reasoning, we also need to roll the CLI changes into this PR?

if anything is to be linked, i would tie the doc and CLI updates into one PR.
@csantanapr @psuter Both `whisk.trigger()` and `whisk.invoke()` are now implemented to return a promise. Have at it!
@markusthoemmes i just pushed a change to the docs. for sequential updates like this, do i need to rebase the two commits into one?

I would preferred to have everything in one PR as general rule (code, tests, doc), but that's just a personal preference.
If @starpit wiling to include the doc and CLI updates in this PR, that's OK by me.

Should we update both CLIs? (python and go)
@bjustin-ibm changes LGTM, 👍  for consolidation code in `post` method

watson-developer-cloud is updated now to use 1.12.4
https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/core/nodejs6Action/Dockerfile#L59

Use default nodejs6 runtime,
if you have already deploy actions as nodejs 0.12, would need to change the kind to nodejs:6
PG1 90

The API currently ignores the "status" property when creating/updating a rule (PUT). An alternative strategy is to allow PUT to specify the desired state of the rule. The default can still be enabled but this would at least allow one to create a rule in an inactive state which we otherwise can't do after this change.

If we were to do that then --enable in the CLI can be set as the default with a --disable added for symmetry.

i'm trying to think of cases where an atomic create-rule-but-disabled is important. if you aren't ready for your rule to be live, then don't create it.

cf's "no-start" option is important for them, because their push command does not accept all of the necessary arguments for starting. e.g. environment variables and service bindings. so you push the app, which then lets you associate env vars and services... then you start it.

i don't see any reason why we would need to have that kind of two-phase startup, for openwhisk?
@markusthoemmes I lost track of the story with registrators and consul health. Do we still use registrators but pull some public image?
@ioana-blue yep, on spot. We don't build the image ourselves anymore (we never really did i think). This just removes a dead link.
PG1 91 as well.  Don't know how else to test at this point.

PG 84 - passed.
PG 92 - in progress (for updated test case with non-ascii)
Fixed by #927.
@bjustin-ibm - Did the comment above address this issue (i.e. can be closed)?

@rabbah - PR #770 fixes this extra argument handling issue for action and other entities.

```
main action create delme1 a.js
main action create delme2 a.js
main action create delme3 a.js
main action delete delme1 delme2 delme3
error: Invalid argument(s): delme2, delme3.
Run 'wsk --help' for usage.
```
PG 93

@perryibm @rabbah @sjfink 

What's our convention for an action within a sequence that returns some json that contains an `error` field? Does that stop the execution of the sequence? That's what I remember, but I wanted to double-check.

@mdeuser #471 is still open and, once it is resolved, I suspect the CLI may need to react in order to show this new information. I would suggest using a "blocked" label, but it seems this repo doesn't have one already 😞
merged 8bea78bd9a614516ef51d348af5cacaac0799503

wouldn't it be a form of dos for whisk to record throttled activations and theirs trigger input? I would view it differently. The feed (service broker or provider) should retry or track these for you, or we can offer a queued mode to soften these effects by queuing activations until the window rolls over.

I think these should go in here instead: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/ansible/group_vars/all.

@domdom82 @lehoanganh
I suggest we move these tests to `WskBasicCliUsageTests` as they test CLI functional and don't need to run as part of system integration tests.

I haven't come up with a compelling reason.

So if a rule is created always in enabled state, is the required CLI change to just remove (deprecate?) `--enable`?
PG1-96 approved.
LGTM
Yes @rabbah check #1015

could we put a stake like this into the ground?
given #47 , we don't enforce a particular method name. instead, the user needs to specify the java class, node handler, etc. that should be executed for invoking an action.

Some things we could do:
- for `main` detection:
  - give up if more than `N` classes in jar
  - try with classes named `*Main*` first

These will preserve some of the convenience but still fall short in the general case.

The only foolproof solution is to stop detection and force the use of a `--mainClass` flag for Java actions.
iirc, we had decided to move away from main -- is that correct?

To clarify: for Java, we leave the name of the main _class_ flexible but mandate the name of the main _method_ (and its signature, and that it should be `static`). I don't think we intent to change that. It's after all the same principle as vanilla Java applications.

The REST call to create a Java action requires specifying the main class. The CLI, for convenience, figures out the main class by analyzing the jar file. This fails (= takes too long) when the jar file is large, and this is the topic of this issue: there is currently no way to bypass the "convenience", hence the need for a CLI flag (whether we keep the automated detection feature is an orthogonal question).

The JavaScript restriction on `main` is discussed in #47 and is only tangentially related in that the CLI may, e.g., use the same flag to specify the entry point.
Rebased and merged as https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/commit/649e39aee9126fee2c2e2759e8310607d8e8b301. Thanks for the contribution and all the tweaks.
PG 98
This is fix now
This is fix now instructions in vagrant/README.md

Hi @lfzCarlosC I have a PR #1019  under review that fixes this issue do you mind giving a try on your windows box and report back if it now works?

```
git clone --depth=1 -b issue-1002 https://github.com/csantanapr/openwhisk.git
cd openwhisk/tools/vagrant
./hello
```

My two cents: If the developer requires a long running container containing previous state (i.e. cache files) from previous ation/function run, then maybe the workload is not best fit for to be solve using serverless. The workload looks like is best solve by normal deamon/server platform.

I'm not familair with the specific use case but I would solve the problem in a different way if I was going to use serverless. 
If there is a large archive 500MB-1GB that the function needs to be initialize, then I would consider this archive part of the definition of the action. 
I would create a new docker action specific for the function include the 500MB archive and push the docker image. creating, and deleting actions unique actions are trivial in whisk.
Then whisk will use the container at the time of doing the computation and run the docker container containing logic code and archive (model).

Today there is small delay for whisk to pull down and cache the docker action, but this can be optimized in the future if whisk were to offer a docker registry that user can push their docker images to.

i think there are many use cases where a warm action is desirable  (warm action = more consistency in terms of fast invocation time), however, i don't think we shouldn't yet be spending effort on implementing native support for this yet. this feature can technically clearly be done, but introduces more complexity to how the engine behaves, another parameter that needs to be taken account across the board, etc. we should rather focus on improving the primitives first, and add this feature once the foundation is ready for it -- specifically given there is a reasonable workaround available.
let me make sure i understand the proposal correctly: is your suggestion that the user should disable to automatic scanning if it takes too long?

ok, i've updated the WskBasicTests rule test. it now
1. tries to update the rule, and expect CONFLICT
2. disables the rule
3. tries to update the rule, and expect SUCCESS
PG1 99 passed
Sorry, I messed up this one. No idea why it is not updated after I submit new patches.

The current method signature being search for in the CLI is `public static com.google.gson.JsonObject main(com.google.gson.JsonObject)`.  I agree with #47 that this is a bit restrictive.  

As for the time it takes for the CLI to validate that the supplied .jar has a method which conforms to the expected signature, we could have a --validate or --novalidate option on the CLI that can be used to control whether or not the .jar is validated.

@starpit - Just wondering, does the GUI validate the action .jar for the expected invocation signature?
/cc @johnsolm
The GUI doesn't yet support jar-file upload.

The plan,  more concretely (still subject to refinement):
1. add `--main` to `wsk action create|update` to allow client to name `main()`.
2. in the absence of a `--main` command line argument, the client (or API) may assume a default (e.g., `main` or search for `main` in the JAR for java).
3. the client may fail to find a main (for example if there are too many classes in a JAR, and fail as suggested in https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/issues/1018#issuecomment-238030048).

I view `--validate` as an orthogonal feature.

> I agree with #47 that this is a bit restrictive. 

The contexts are different for Node vs Java - it's not common in Node to use `main()` vs `module.export`. So The spirit of #47 is to make the common case more in line with developer experience for Node.

Here's a scenario I was thinking about.  The customer has several actions (say, A, B and C) plus all of the common utility code in a single jar.  This same jar is used to create actions A, B and C - each having a separate invocation method.

Does the `--main` take an argument?  If so, a `--main CLASS.METHOD` argument would handle the scenario I described.

Regarding

```
3. the client may fail to find a main (for example if there are too many classes in a JAR).
```

Is the CLI still expected to validate that the specified/default invocation method exists in the jar?

@mdeuser yes, the idea is for `--main` to take a class name. This is familiar to Java developers who run, e.g.:

```
java -cp ... com.example.MyMain $arg1 $arg2
```

Regarding the validation, that's orthogonal. The CLI currently runs no check for any of the runtimes. E.g. it doesn't even check that the code parses, let alone that `main` exists, so I would say we could do it, but as a separate issue.

A possibly user-friendly experience could be to do something similar to the way `jar` command works, allowing to specify the name of the entrypoint **class** that has the `main()` method (`jar cfe my-jar-file.jar <my.entrypoint.class.that.has.Java.main.method> <class_files_to_include_in_jar>`). So, similarly to what @rabbah suggested, the syntax could be: `wsk action create/update <action-name> <my-action.jar> --entrypoint <my.entrypoint.class.that.has.Whisk.main.method>`

I will handle this once we update our watson-developer-cloud npm package to 2.x.  Right now we are using 1.12.4 for our nodejs6 container.  In 1.12.4 the API is still language_translation and not language_translator.

@psuter - Thanks for the clarification.  The only "validation" I was referring to is the CLI's examination of the jar file to ensure the expected endpoint (name and signature) exists.  In Rodric's proposal, it sounds like the CLI will still attempt this sanity check whether or not the endpoint is explicitly stated via the `--main` argument.  Right?  Or, when the endpoint is not specified, will the CLI skip this check and send the jar as-is to the server?

Seems to me that if the test is specifically testing actions created under whisk.system that the test should live in openwhisk-catalog now and not openwhisk.  Openwhisk-catalog will now be the one who installs actions under whisk.system right?

@mbehrendt, @rabbah  another option could be to set a timeout (e.g., 1 minute), to do our best finding the entrypoint (if was not specified), to notify the user that entrypoint has not been found, and suggest setting it explicitly with --entrypoint (or whatever).
hm -- what if more than one class gets found that matches the criteria? we'd have ask the user for input anyway...
